newsitem.title: USA: Intel, Kodak collaborate on PC imaging.
newsitem.headline: Intel, Kodak collaborate on PC imaging.

text.p: Intel Corp and Eastman Kodak Co said on Monday that they will work together to advance industry specifications for consumer use of digital imaging on personal computer systems.
The two companies said they were trying to advance the ability to edit, store, share and publish images easily.

Craig Barrett, chief operating officer of Intel, and Eastman Kodak Chairman and CEO George Fisher, who appeared by video conference connection, said their companies would work together to integrate their technology capabilities.
For example, FlashPix, which Kodak developed with Hewlett-Packard Co, Live Picture and Microsoft Corp will soon be able to utilize the speed of Intel's MMX multimedia processing technology.
Intel's Universal Serial Bus, flash memory such as its Intel Miniature Card and silicon capabilities will be combined with Kodak's imaging technologies to accelerate the use of imaging applications.
The companies noted that digital still camera sales are projected to grow to more than 15 million a year by the year 2000, according to independent researchers.
Fisher said in addition to its FlashPix involvement, Kodak has created what he said was the largest portfolio of digital photography products in the industry, including retail stations.

Analysts said the move by Intel to define its own miniature card format will require other suppliers to rework their flash memory to work with Intel's standard. ((sam.perry@reuters.com, Palo Alto Bureau 415 846 5400))
